title: Turns out, most 'period painkillers' are exactly the same as normal ones
text:
From Cosmopolitan

If you’ve ever wondered what the difference is between the various painkillers that claim to directly target period pain (Panadol Period Pain and Nurofen Express Period Pain capsules, I’m looking directly at you and your luminous pink packaging), the answer, according to Jamie Urquhart, Superintendent Pharmacist for Now Patient, is nothing.

Yes, you read that correctly – there’s literally no difference between Panadol’s period cramp-focussed product and their regular Panadol Extra Advance painkillers. Ditto Nurofen Express Period Pain capsules when compared with Nurofen Express Liquid capsules.

“It’s all in the marketing,” explains Urquhart, a pharmacist of over 18 years. “The drugs are usually the same, but patients may not realise the original brand is good for period pain, as for example, they may previously have taken them for an ankle injury. It’s understandable why some patients and customers get confused when selecting a product.”

Hence the clever marketers who jazz up the packaging with typically “feminine” colours to draw in those with beastly cramps looking for instant relief. The only difference, is sometimes the price. But, this is great to know if you've ever paced the aisles of Boots freaking out because the period-designed pain relief are all out of stock, thinking other varieties won't quite cut it.

Photo credit: Getty Images More

So what would Urquhart advise for treating the pain of monthly womb torture? As a first line treatment, he recommends ibuprofen or aspirin, however, these aren’t suitable for everyone (for example those with asthma or stomach, kidney or liver problems). Aspirin should not be taken by anyone under 16 years of age, either.



“Paracetamol is another option, but studies have shown that it does not reduce pain as well as ibuprofen or aspirin. Stronger painkillers such as naproxen (Feminax Ultra) or codeine containing painkillers can be purchased from pharmacies as second line treatment too [if the former suggestions are ineffective].”

Other non-medicinal options include a trusty hot water bottle, quitting smoking (who knew?), exercising and Transcutaneous Electronic Nerve Stimulation (TENS, which to the uninitiated are little machines with patches attached designed to relax muscles). So there you have it, the pink packaging is literally just that... packaging.

Jamie Urquhart is a Superintendent Pharmacist for Now Patient, an online pharmacy and GP service.
